STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
April 17, 2019
Demetrius Starling
St Clair County DHHS
220 Fort St
Port Huron, MI 48060
RE: License #: CP740201421
St Clair County DHHS
220 Fort St
Port Huron, MI 48060
Dear Mr. Starling:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
04/15/2019. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 An explanation why previous CAP have not been obtained and
maintained compliance for rules found in repeat noncompliance.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3012
Enclosure:
Jamie Reinke
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP740201421
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling, Administrator
Jennifer Wrayno, Designee
Name of Facility: St Clair County DHHS
Facility Address: 220 Fort St
Port Huron, MI 48060
Facility Telephone #: (810) 966-2173
Original Issuance Date: 08/17/1995
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s): 04/15/2019

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient
number of competent staff to carry out the provisions
covered by these rules. The workload for each staff
member shall not be more than any of the following:
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services worker
for purposes of providing direct services in foster care,
independent living, adoption, or post adoption services or a
combination thereof.
Five social service workers were over the caseload monitoring workload specified by
the updated Communication Issuance 17-124 Foster Care 13:1 caseload
compliance that was issued and dated 9/25/2017. It was recommended that a
worker caseload is 13:1. Two social service worker had a caseload of sixteen, two
social service workers had a caseload of fourteen and one social service worker had
a case load of fifteen.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in
the agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the
department's licensing authority within 5 working days in
the manner prescribed by the department.
One of three special evaluation reports reviewed, one report was initiated on
08/07/2018, the report was submitted to Lansing on 08/15/2018, eight days late.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) Reason for the change in placement.
Two of eight case records were reviewed, two did not have documentation of why
the child’s placement was changed. One child was placed six times, there was no
documentation as to why this child placement was changed or disrupted. One child
was move once and there was no documentation discussing the reason or the
removal of the child.
4

REPEAT VIOLATION FROM INTERIM 2018
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS
MiSACWIS
(Commitment
22)
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated
child welfare information system (MiSACWIS) which will be
the primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
The agency is not consistent in uploading their documentation in MiSACWIS for
foster care and independent living. The documents are:
 Medical passports quarterly updates
 Unannounced home visits
 69/69b
 Family team meetings
 Parent Agency Treatment Plans signed by parents/caregivers and children
over 14
 School records
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM INTERIM 2018
ISEP 6.12 a & b Maximum Children in a Foster Home
Pg.20
If more than 3 foster children are placed in a foster home or
more than 6 total children reside in a home, does a waiver,
(PER) signed by the DCWL director exist.
One of eight case records were reviewed, one child was placed in the foster home
on 6/29/18 and 7/31/2018. He went to the hospital and back to the foster home.
There was no PER before the child placement in the foster home. The PER was
completed on 8/1/2018 and approved by DCWL director on 8/10/2018. There was
more than three foster children in the home on 7/31/2018.
5

3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy 722- Family Team Meetings
06B pg. 2-6
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include
extended family, friends, neighbors, community-based service
providers, community representatives, tribal representatives,
for Indian children, or other professionals involved with the
family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required
time frames as out-lined in the following tables…
In five of twenty – two service plans reviewed, two FTM’s did not occur for the child
within 30 days of the service plan and there were no uploading/treatment plans for the
parent. In one case record three of the child’s service plans had no documentation of
the activity reports for the child.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM INTERIM 2018
DHHS Policy Caseworker Contacts. Unannounced Home visit.
FOM 722-6 H
Pg. 7
The caseworker must make an unannounced visit to the placement
every quarter. This unannounced visit must be noted in the social
work contacts of the case service plan.
Six of twenty- two service plans reviewed, six case records did not have documentation
of an unannounced home visit.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM INTERIM 2018
6

DHHS Policy Caseworker Contact child in out of Home Placement.
FOM 722-6 H
Pg. 5
At least one contact each month must take place at the child’s
placement location.
One of eight case records reviewed, one did not have documentation of contact with the
child in the home for the reporting period of January 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM INTERIM 2018
DHHS Policy Sibling Visitation and ongoing interaction.
FOM 722 -06l
Pg 11 -12
Siblings not placed together shall have at least one visit per
month unless the visit may be harmful to one or more of the
siblings, the sibling is placed out- of- state, the distance
between the sibling’s placements is more than 50 miles and
one child is placed with a relative, or one of the siblings is
above the age of 16 and refuses such visits. (The above visit
exception must be recorded in MiSACWIS). The plan for sibling
visits and all reasonable efforts to assure that visits take place
must be documented within the sibling visitation section of the
case service plan.
Two out of eight case records reviewed, two did not have documentation of a sibling
visits. One case record had no sibling visits for six months. One case record did not
have sibling visitation for the month of November.
DHHS Policy Required Participation in Development – foster
FOM 722 – 08C parent/caregiver.
The foster parent/caregiver is required to sign each parent
agency treatment plan.
7

Nine of twenty -two case service plans were reviewed. One case record service plan
had no activity report. One case record the child had three PATP’s where the caregiver
did not sign. Two case records reviewed the PATP’s were not uploaded and three child
records in the service plans the boxes were not checked indicating that the caregiver
participated in the development of the service plan.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM INTERIM 2018
DHHS Policy Transfer of student Records to New School.
FOM 723
Pg. 5-6
The caseworker must request student records using DHHS -
942, Education Record Release. Requested records should
include but are not limited to grades/unofficial transcript.
Two of eight case records reviewed, two did not have documentation of report cards
uploaded in MiSACWIS.
DHHS Policy Medical Passports
FOM 801 – page
14-15
All medical information required by policy and/or law must be
provided to the foster parent. This includes copies of the
medical and dental examinations (if available) and the
information required in the medical passport. For children first
entering foster care, the initial medical passport must be
provided to the caregivers within two weeks of the child's
placement date. The actual date the caregivers receive the
medical passport must be documented in MiSACWIS. All
medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information. Placement agency
foster care (PAFC) providers must provide a copy of the
medical passport to MDHHS monitoring staff as it is updated
but no less often than annually. Each foster care worker who
transfers a child's medical passport to another foster care
worker must sign and date the medical passport verifying that
s/he has sought and obtained the necessary information under
law and MDHHS policy. An updated medical passport is
provided to: Legal parents, if the child is a temporary court
ward.
All medical and mental health professionals to whom the child
is referred and accepted for treatment.
- The child’s foster care provider at or prior to each placement.
This includes foster homes, relative placements and residential
facilities.
8

- Legal parents quarterly and at reunification, if the child is a
temporary court ward.
- All medical and mental health professionals to whom the
child is referred and accepted for treatment
Two of twenty -two child records reviewed did not show documentation that the medical
passport was signed by the foster parent/caregiver as required by the standard.
Four of twenty – two child records reviewed did not show documentation the child’s
medical passport was updated quarterly.
One of twenty -two child records indicated that the child was placed on 6/29/18 and
7/31/18. His medical passport was signed on 4/9/2019.
DHHS Follow – up Health Care
Policy FOM 801
Pg 8-9
The caseworker is responsible for reviewing the information
within the child’s Well Exam form, the DHHS 1664, Youth Health
Record, Dental form and other medical, dental and mental health
treatment is recommended, the caseworker must ensure that the
recommendations are followed. Additionally, follow-up
recommendations received from emergency room or urgent
care visits require that the caseworker ensure treatment
recommendation are followed by the foster care provider.
Two of twenty – two case records reviewed, two case records did not have documentation
of medical follow -up. One case record indicated on 11/18/18 dental examination form
stated a recommendation to extract teeth at oral surgeon. There was no updated
information. One case record did not update information regarding a child’s dental fillings
scheduled for 8/15/2018.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
9

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
It was reported that the foster child (age 5) was outside alone unattended. The child
rode her bicycle outside of the subdivision to a busy main road. The foster child was
alone and unsupervised. The foster parent was unaware of the foster child’s
location. The police was called out and the foster child was returned back to the
foster home. Once the foster child was returned back to the foster home there was
a lot of yelling between the foster parent and the child. It is unknown what was said.
The agency found the foster parent in non-compliance with R 9201 Foster parent
qualifications, R 9205 Records check, R 9403 foster parent duties. The agency
recommended revocation due to the foster parent stating she was unaware that she
had to have constant supervision on a 5- year old child and that the foster parent
showed that she was not able to provide the appropriate care, protection and
supervision of any child placed in her home. The agency handling of the special
evaluations appears appropriate.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted a corrective action plan for the 07/18/2018 interim inspection
report. The corrective action plan was accepted on 8/15/2018.
The non -compliances were: R400.12207 Staff responsibilities, R12404 Placement,
R12405 Change of placement, R12413 Medical and dental care policy, R12418
Development of service plans, R12507 Medical/dental health care, ISEP 6.18
Relative foster parent licensing timeliness, ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS, DHHS Policy
FOM 722 6B, family Team Meetings DHHS Policy FOM 722.6H Unannounced visit,
DHHS Policy FOM 722.08C Foster Care Parent Agency Treatment Plan and Service
Agreement. (Signatures) and DHHS Policy FOM 722 -09C Foster Care Action
Summary Requirements. The agency addressed some of the non-compliance but had
some repeated non-compliance from the last review period.
VII. DCWL ANALYST CONCERNS ADDRESSED:
Safety Alert #1:
Concern: The agency does not provide all known information when requesting
placement.
10

The agency does not respect the parameters of the foster license. The
foster parents have been asked to take a child outside of their age range.
Resolution: The agency reported in emergency situations where placement is needed
and not secured, staff do contact homes on the list to see if they would
be willing to change their licensing parameters and accept placement.
However, placement would not occur until the parameters were changed
through DCWL to ensure they are compliant prior to placement.
The agency responded that at times of a proposed placement, licensing is
only able to provide information given to them from CPS/FC. Thus,
information found after placement may not always be provided to licensing
at the time of placement.
Safety Alert #2:
Concern: The foster care worker was not making monthly home visits to the home.
The foster care worker does not make unannounced visits to the home.
Resolution: The agency response was that face to face visitations in the relative
caregiver home occurred on the following dates completed by the foster
care specialist. The visits occurred from July 13, 2017 until February 5,
2019 announced and unannounced. They were all documented in the case
service plans.
Home visits occurred in the parental home from 3/1/19 to 3/25/19 as the
children was returned to the parental home. The judge ordered
termination of DHHS care and supervision effective 3/21/2019.
The agency responded in reviewing the visitation dates and looking for
trends some visits occurred at the end of one month and the beginning
of the following month.
Safety Alert #3:
Concern: The foster parent is using a drop side crib for one of the toddlers placed
in the home.
Resolution: Both children in the home are over the age of 2. Due to the age of the
children, the family converted the non-compliant crib into a toddler bed.
Picture is attached.
11

Safety Alert #4:
Concern: No safety concerns was reported for this home.
Resolution: No resolution required.
Safety Alert #5:
Concern: No safety concerns was reported for this home.
Resolution: No resolution required.
Safety Alert #6:
Concern: The foster care worker does not make unannounced visits to the home.
The relative did not sign the treatment plan for the child placed in the home.
Resolution: The agency response was that prior worker did not complete any
unannounced home visits. Since the case has been transferred to a
new worker an unannounced home visit occurred on 2/27/2019 and will
occur from this point forward.
Prior to the worker transfer there were no PATP’s signed by the caregiver.
Since the case transferred PATP’s have been provided to caregiver and
will be provided from this point forward.
It should be noted that the agency was in violation during this renewal
period for unannounced visits and the signing of PATP’s.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
12

04/17/2019
________________________________________
Pinkey Brown Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
April 23, 2019
________________________________________
Linda Tansil Date
Area Manager
